metadata.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. V. V. Oak & Ors.

facts.text: Continental Mutual Assurance Company Ltd., Poona was a mutual company with no share capital, incorporated in 1946, carrying on only life insurance business.
Respondents V. V. Oak and S. V. Oak made five deposits totaling Rs. 7,408.81 in the last weeks of December 1950 and 1951, carrying interest at 4-1/2% per annum.
First actuarial valuation as on December 31, 1950 showed a loss of Rs. 72,924; balance-sheet showed assets totaling Rs. 11,216, perhaps not realizable.
Certificate of registration cancelled in 1952; Controller of Insurance threatened winding up if insolvency not removed.
In July 1952, all Directors guaranteed to make good deficit before end of October 1952; depositors agreed not to press for return until deficit removed.
Controller revived certificate; deficit not removed by October end; Chairman informed purchasing immovable property worth Rs. 49,000 from deposits, not to be returned except from surplus assets.
Controller directed deposits to be paid from future valuation surpluses, not surplus assets; company agreed; depositors including respondents gave undertakings.
Letter dated 7th November 1952 from Assistant Controller: deposits repayable only out of future valuation surpluses and not out of surplus assets.

Undertaking dated 29th November 1952 by V. V. Oak (for self and S. V. Oak): deposit of Rs. 7,408 repayable only out of adequate surplus along with interest; interest from last valuation out of 7-1/2% of surplus retrospectively.
Actuarial valuation as on December 31, 1954 disclosed deficit of Rs. 89,923.
Under Life Insurance Emergency Provisions Ordinance, 1956 followed by Act 9 of 1956, business taken over by Government of India on January 19, 1956.

On passing of Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 (31 of 1956), controlled business of all insurers vested in LIC on September 1, 1956; for this company carrying only life business, all business vested under s.7.
Company showed no valuation surplus; insolvent under Insurance Act when taken over; huge deficit likely on Sept 1, 1956.
LIC showed enormous valuation surplus; respondents claimed repayment from LIC's surplus as condition fulfilled.
Respondents filed suit No. 149 of 1959 in Bombay City Civil Court on January 5, 1959 after s.80 notice; suit pending.
LIC filed petition before Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur on October 5, 1959 (Case No. 31/XII of 1959) for declaration no repayment entitlement and injunction against suit.
Tribunal on December 30, 1959 held amounts not repayable as contracts not subsisting pre-vesting due to no surplus; rejected s.65 Contract Act claim; suit does not lie; earlier injunction sent.
Depositors filed Special Civil Application No. 279 of 1960 under Arts. 226/227 in Bombay High Court.
Bombay High Court on July 29, 1960 reversed Tribunal: s.9 LIC Act substitutes LIC; liable from own business; s.28 surplus after all liabilities; remit to Tribunal.
Appeal by certificate to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the deposits are repayable by LIC from its valuation surplus, given undertakings postponing repayment until adequate valuation surplus, and effect of s.9 LIC Act vesting.
Whether s.28 LIC Act bars repayment of such deposits from LIC's surplus.
Whether contracts subsisted immediately before appointed day under s.9 LIC Act, despite contingent nature due to no surplus.

petitioner_arguments.text: Undertakings meant repayment only from Insurance Company's valuation surplus, not LIC's; no such surplus pre-vesting, so contracts not subsisting/enforceable under s.9.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Life Insurance Corporation Act s.9; Insurance Act 1938 (Forms A-I, valuation surplus technical meaning)

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternatively, if from LIC surplus, s.28 precludes payment as surplus allocated 95% to policy-holders, remainder as Government directs.

respondent_arguments.text: S.9 explicitly substitutes LIC in contracts; full force and effect unless expressly overridden; contingent liability subsists.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Life Insurance Corporation Act s.9; no override by ss.14,15,36

respondent_arguments.text: S.28 does not bar; if it does, ultra vires Arts.19,31.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Life Insurance Corporation Act s.28; Constitution Arts.19,31

court_reasoning.text: Contracts subsisted pre-vesting as contingent liabilities; s.9 substitutes LIC fully unless expressly provided otherwise; no such provision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contingent liability on vesting date becomes LIC's liability.

court_reasoning.text: Repayable from actuarial surplus of LIC as business merged, no separate valuation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: LIC as substituted party has surplus.

court_reasoning.text: S.28 surplus has technical actuarial meaning per Insurance Act; 95% to policy-holders, remainder as Government directs, but s.9 compulsive; read harmoniously, no bar to s.9 obligations; Government expected to regard liabilities.

holdings.text: Contracts binding on LIC under s.9; deposits payable from LIC's actuarial surplus.
S.28 does not bar fulfilment of s.9 obligations when read harmoniously.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 (31 of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of business in LIC; substitution in contracts; valuation and surplus utilization; no bar to contract liabilities.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Emergency Provisions Act, 1956 (9 of 1956)
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Potential ultra vires challenge to s.28; writ petition.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view that contracts are binding on LIC under s.9 and s.28 does not bar repayment from surplus; appeal against High Court remand order dismissed implicitly by affirming liability.
outcome.relief_granted: Liability on LIC to repay deposits from actuarial surplus affirmed.

key_quotes.text: "Unless otherwise expressly provided by or under this Act, all contracts... shall... be of as full force and effect against or in favour of the Corporation..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.9 LIC Act central to substitution of LIC in contracts.

key_quotes.text: "We think that on this harmonious construction we must hold that s. 28 does not put any bar in the way of the Corporation in the fulfilment of its obligations arising under s. 9."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the deposits or loans obtained by the Company to cover its insolvency are to be repaid only out of the future valuation surpluses and not out of surplus assets."
key_quotes.speaker: court
